ingredients:
2 oz. bourbon or rye whiskey
1 sugar cube or 1 tsp. superfine
sugar or 2 tsp. simple syrup
2 dashes Angostura bitters
(or any bitters, really)
method: Place sugar cube in glass and soak with bitters and a few drops of water; crush to paste with wooden muddler. You can use loose sugar instead, or simple syrup (skip the added water if the latter), but the ritual contributes to the experience. Add whiskey and stir to mix and dissolve sugar; add ice and stir again to chill. Garnish.

ingredients:
2 oz. rye whiskey
1 oz. sweet vermouth
2 dashes Angostura bitters
method: Stir with ice to chill; strain into chilled glass. Garnish.
note: Use bourbon if the cause moves you. This is a good drink to try out different bitters —Boker’s and Abbott’s are very good, as are Dale DeGroff’s aromatic pimento bitters.

ingredients:
1 oz. bourbon
1 oz. sweet vermouth
1 oz. Campari
method: Build drink in ice–filled rocks glass; stir to combine, and garnish with orange wheel. To serve straight-up, stir ingredients with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass; garnish with orange twist.

ingredients:
2 oz. rye whiskey or bourbon
3/4 oz. lemon juice
1/2 oz. simple syrup
1/4 oz. egg white (optional)
method:
Shake with ice to chill; strain into chilled sour or cocktail glass, or strain into ice–filled rocks glass.

Variation: Float 1/2 oz. of dry red wine atop the finished drink to make a New York Sour.

ingredients:

1 oz. sweet vermouth
1 oz. Campari
garnish: small orange wheel or orange twist
method: Build drink in ice–filled rocks glass; stir to combine, and garnish with orange wheel. To serve straight-up, stir ingredients with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass; garnish with orange twist.

ingredients:
11/2 oz. gin

1/4 oz. Campari
1/4 oz. Cointreau
method: Shake with ice to chill; strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish.

ingredients:
1 oz. gin
1 oz. green Chartreuse
1 oz. sweet vermouth
1 dash orange bitters
method: Stir with ice to chill; strain into chilled glass. Garnish.

ingredients:

3/4 oz. lime juice
3/4 oz. green Chartreuse
3/4 oz. maraschino liqueur
method: Shake with ice to chill; strain into chilled glass.

ingredients:

ingredients:
2 oz. vodka
1/2 lime
4 oz. chilled ginger beer
method: Squeeze lime half into ice-filled mug or glass and add remaining ingredients; stir and garnish.

ingredients:
1 1/2 oz. vodka
1/4 oz. green Chartreuse
1/8 oz. Cointreau

2 oz. vodka
1 oz. Cointreau
1 oz.cranberry juice
1 oz. Rose’s lime juice (Or add 1/2 ounce fresh lime juice and 1/2 ounce simple syrup)
method: Shake ingredients with cracked ice, then strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Add sugar to the rim if you like.

ingredients:
1 oz. reposado tequila prefered
1 oz. sweet vermouth
1 oz. Campari
method: Build in ice–filled glass, stir to combine. Garnish. Tip: Substitute mezcal for tequila.

ingredients:
2 oz. blanco tequila
3/4 oz. lime juice
1 oz. Cointreau
method: Shake with ice to chill; strain into chilled cocktail glass or rocks glass filled with fresh ice. Option: Before mixing drink, moisten the lip of the serving glass with a cut lime wedge, and rim the glass with coarse salt.

ingredients:
2 oz. tequila (blanco or reposado,
your call)
3/4 oz. lime juice
3/4 oz. agave syrup, to taste
method: Shake with ice to chill, strain into glass filled with fresh ice. Garnish with lime wedge. Option: Before mixing drink, moisten the lip of the serving glass with a cut lime wedge, and rim the glass with coarse salt.

ingredients:
3 ounces squeezed white grapefruit juice
2 ounces blanco or silver tequila
½ ounce freshly squeezed lime juice
½ ounce agave nectar
Sea salt to rim the glass
Club soda
method: Fill cocktail shaker two-thirds full with ice. Add grapefruit juice, tequila, lime juice and agave nectar. Shake well and strain into an ice-filled Collins glass rimmed with sea salt. Top with a splash of club soda, and garnish with lime wheel.
note: Grapefruit soda may be hard to find. This is an updated version of the paloma. It was the best among the handful of paloma recipes I tested.
